title: Introductions and Pronouns
description: A quick overview of some simple greetings and introductions while we're getting familiar with the features of the platform.

elements.content: We'll start one of the best known Māori greetings, commonly heard in Aotearoa. Don't worry too much at this stage about what each individual word means, just take the opportunity to get familiar with reading te reo Māori and saying it aloud to yourself.

elements.note: Listen to the [recording](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/2608) on Te Aka and note how the two vowels in {{ki**a o**ra}} blend into one another!
This can be said to a group of people. If you're only talking to one friend, you drop {{mā}} and say {{kia ora, e hoa!}}

elements.content:
While {{kia ora}} is used to say hello, its literal translation is closer to `be well`.

It's commonly considered an informal way to say hello.
These are some examples of other informal greetings and farewells:

A common and more formal way to greet (or thank) someone is to use {{tēnā koe}} which roughly translates to "there you are".

However, this is only the correct form of this greeting if you are speaking to one person. If you are speaking to more than one person, you use a different word instead of {{koe}}. This is because of the way that pronouns work in te reo Māori.

In English we use the word "you" as our second person pronoun. Unlike the first person pronoun where we change the word depending on whether we're talking about one person or multiple people ("I" or "we"), we use the word "you" for singular and plural cases (unless you use y'all). The second person pronoun in te reo Māori is more precise and a different form of the word is used depending on whether you're referring to one person, two people, or three or more people.

So we have [[word|koe|w-koe]] for one person, [[word|kōrua|w-koorua]] for two people, and [[word|koutou|w-koutou]] for three or more people. 

Depending on how many people you are speaking to you might use one of the following phrases (the highlighted word can be scrolled up or down to change the sentence):

translations.Tēnā koutou: Hello/Thank you (to three or more people)

elements.content: There are a number of other differences between pronouns in English and te reo Māori, but let's keep it simple for now and focus on those ones!

The following sentences are ways to ask someone's name, as well as how to answer that question:

This is a good opportunity to learn another pronoun you'll want to know how to use. [[word|Au|w-au]] or [[word|ahau|w-ahau]] is how you say "I" or "me" in te reo Māori. You can use either one interchangeably and can pick one based on what feels most natural in the flow of the sentence. Which word you choose can make some minor differences to the surrounding words that get paired with them, but that's something we can look at later. For now, they can be considered to be equivalent to one another.

In English, when someone asks "who are you?" you might say "I am Mary".

Take a look at how a similar sentence looks in te reo Māori:

Observe that in both pairs of examples, the answer takes a similar format to the question. The sentence structure is very similar in both cases, with a different pronoun and the question word {{wai}} or "who" swapped out for the answer. This is a common question/answer format in te reo Māori and we'll investigate how it works as we progress through the lessons.

In {{te ao Māori}} (the Māori world), it's common for formal greetings to include details about where you come from to communicate to the listener who your ancestors are and who you might know. This gives them an opportunity to recognise and share connections that they may have with you as part of getting to know one another.

These are some of the ways that you might communicate where you come from:

elements.note:
Note that {{nō}} is a possessive term, so the question is literally asking `to where do you belong?`

Because of this detail, it can be considered improper for non-Māori to use {{nō}} to claim a connection to somewhere in Aotearoa. Not every listener is going to be find this inappropriate, but it can be more respectful to use an alternative way of describing where you come from such as some of the  options on the next page.

elements.content: The final pronoun we'll introduce in this exercise is [[word|ia|w-ia]] which is the singular third-person pronoun used for he, she and singular they:

elements.note: The [[ref|tūkapi|tukapi]] (pronoun) {{ia}} refers to one person without reference to their gender, unlike he/she in English.
You can use {{nō}} to describe a line of connection to a place or to an {{iwi}} (tribe).

elements.content: These are some other ways to describe where you live and where you come from:

elements.sentence: I whānau mai koe ki hea?
I whānau mai au ki Kirikiriroa.
I tipu ake au ki Heretaunga.

elements.content: These are just some examples of how to describe where you're from in normal conversation. A more detailed description of how to formally provide your background will be covered in a later lesson.
